citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult female Australian Shepherd dog (ID# 53975) has a wound on the right hind leg that is not being treated. The
wound measures approximately 0.5 inches and contains a scab with hair loss around the wound. The animal was not
seen scratching or irritating the site. The licensee states they have not been treating the wound. Wounds that are
untreated can cause infection, pain, and discomfort to the animal. Failure to treat problems of animal health can lead to
delays in providing proper care to animals resulting in worsening of their condition. The licensee must maintain programs
of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases
and injuries. Correct by treating the wound as directed by a veterinarian.

The licensee is not using the required APHIS Form 7006 for disposition records for puppies and does not have a
variance. The licensee is currently using computerized disposition records for puppies. The use of APHIS Form 7006 is
required as it allows for proper traceability and management of regulated animals at a facility.
Each dealer shall use Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the
information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section. Provided, that if a dealer or exhibitor who uses a computerized
recordkeeping system believes that APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the
information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the dealer or exhibitor may request a variance from the
requirement to use APHIS Form 7006. Correct by ensuring all required information is fully and correctly documented on
an APHIS Form 7006 or by obtaining a variance.

Several primary enclosures contain carpet that is in disrepair with frayed edges. An enclosure housing an adult female
dog with 4 puppies, an adult female dog with 6 puppies, and an adult female dog with 4 puppies has carpet that is frayed
and damaged. Frayed edges can be injurious to the regulated animal as they could ingest the material or could cause
entrapment. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities—including houses, dens,
and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility—that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be
replaced when worn or soiled. The carpets must be maintained without frayed edges.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 14, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult female Australian Shepherd dog (ID# 53975) has a wound on the right hind leg that is not being treated. The 
wound measures approximately 0.5 inches and contains a scab with hair loss around the wound. The animal was not 
seen scratching or irritating the site. The licensee states they have not been treating the wound. Wounds that are 
untreated can cause infection, pain, and discomfort to the animal. Failure to treat problems of animal health can lead to 
delays in providing proper care to animals resulting in worsening of their condition. The licensee must maintain programs 
of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases 
and injuries. Correct by treating the wound as directed by a veterinarian. 
2.75(a)(2) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee is not using the required APHIS Form 7006 for disposition records for puppies and does not have a 
variance. The licensee is currently using computerized disposition records for puppies. The use of APHIS Form 7006 is 
required as it allows for proper traceability and management of regulated animals at a facility. 
 
Each dealer shall use Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the 
information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section. Provided, that if a dealer or exhibitor who uses a computerized 
recordkeeping system believes that APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the 
information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the dealer or exhibitor may request a variance from the 
requirement to use APHIS Form 7006. Correct by ensuring all required information is fully and correctly documented on 
an APHIS Form 7006 or by obtaining a variance. 
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several primary enclosures contain carpet that is in disrepair with frayed edges. An enclosure housing an adult female 
dog with 4 puppies, an adult female dog with 6 puppies, and an adult female dog with 4 puppies has carpet that is frayed 
and damaged. Frayed edges can be injurious to the regulated animal as they could ingest the material or could cause 
entrapment. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities—including houses, dens,

and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility—that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be 
replaced when worn or soiled. The carpets must be maintained without frayed edges. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 14, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
